newsitem.title: USA: Boeing profits fell in quarter as sales surged.
newsitem.headline: Boeing profits fell in quarter as sales surged.

text.p: Boeing Co. said Monday that its profits fell in the second quarter from the year-earlier period, when results were boosted by one-time gains, while sales jumped on strong demand for aircraft and other products.

The world's largest commercial aircraft maker said net income fell to $399 million, or 55 cents a share, in the quarter, excluding the effects of an employee stock plan, from $468 million, or 68 cents a share, a year earlier. One-time gains of $176 million, or 25 cents a share, boosted 1996 results.
Sales surged 48 percent to $9.29 billion from $6.28 billion as the company ramped up commercial aircraft production and expanded its space and missiles business.

The results for the latest quarter fell below Wall Street estimates of 59 cents a share, according to First Call, which tracks analysts' forecasts. Boeing stock fell $1.19 to $54.875 in morning trading on the New York Stock Exchange.

Boeing Chairman Phil Condit said the rapid increase in production resulted in "a substantial increase in employment, material and fabrication demand at the company and its suppliers." High overtime levels and parts shortages have caused a "near-term decline in productivity," he added.

Boeing said it expects to deliver 340 to 350 commercial jetliners this year, up from a previous projection of 340. Last year Boeing delivered just 218 jets as the company reached the end of a long industry downturn.

Boeing said it expects revenues of $34 billion this year excluding sales at McDonnell Douglas Corp., which it plans to acquire in a deal scheduled to close next week despite an expected vote by European regulators to reject it.
Boeing's results were stated excluding the effects of the company's employee stock plan, which would have trimmed earnings in the latest quarter to $334 million, or 48 cents a share.
